title: CNN's Going Green explores the innovations protecting and purifying water - PR Newswire
summary: CNN's 'Going Green' explores innovative solutions to protect and purify water. The episode features companies like Cape RADD, Elemental Water Makers, Epic Cleantec, Glanris, and Bloom, each offering unique approaches to water conservation, purification, and sustainable materials. These companies use diverse methods, ranging from high-tech shark monitoring to converting agricultural waste into water filtration media, showcasing a range of solutions to address water scarcity and pollution.

title: Sustainable Shoes: 13 Brands Creating Planet-Friendly Footwear - Pebble Magazine
summary: The article highlights 13 sustainable shoe brands, showcasing their use of recycled materials, ethical manufacturing practices, and commitment to reducing environmental impact.  The brands offer various styles, from sneakers and boots to sandals and flats, catering to diverse needs and preferences.  Each brand is detailed with information on their materials, sustainability goals, and efforts towards fair labor practices.

title: New lithium discovery highlights why we never run out of resources - Yield PRO magazine
summary: The article argues that resource scarcity predictions, such as those surrounding lithium, are often flawed. It highlights that known reserves increase as prices rise and companies actively search for new deposits. Additionally, the author emphasizes that rising prices encourage consumers to economize and innovate, leading to substitutes for scarce resources. This suggests that resource scarcity fears may be overblown and innovation will likely address any shortages.

title: Victoriaâ€™s New Recycling Scheme Is Serving Us Utopian Slay - The Latch
summary: Victoria, Australia has launched a new Container Deposit Scheme (CDS Vic) offering a 10-cent refund for returned cans, cartons, and bottles. The scheme aims to reduce litter and increase recycling rates, creating 600 jobs and supporting a more sustainable future. While the scheme is lauded for its environmental benefits and positive impact on recycling rates, it remains to be seen how Victorians will engage with the system and if it will lead to sustainable behavioral changes.
